title: Network Layer
description: Understanding IP addressing, routing, and network layer protocols

keyConcepts.title: Network Layer Functions
keyConcepts.description: Layer 3 provides logical addressing (IP addresses), routing between networks, and path determination. It encapsulates transport layer segments into packets.

keyConcepts.title: IPv4 Addressing
keyConcepts.description: 32-bit hierarchical addressing system providing ~4.3 billion addresses. Format: xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx (dotted decimal notation).

keyConcepts.title: IPv6 Addressing
keyConcepts.description: 128-bit addressing system created to solve IPv4 address exhaustion. Provides simplified header, improved efficiency, and virtually unlimited addresses.

keyConcepts.title: Routing Process
keyConcepts.description: Routers examine the destination IP address in packet headers and use routing tables to determine the best path to forward packets toward their destination.

keyConcepts.title: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit)
keyConcepts.description: The data link layer passes the MTU value up to the network layer. IP uses this to ensure packets don't exceed the physical medium's size limits, fragmenting if necessary.

keyConcepts.title: Connectionless Protocol
keyConcepts.description: IP is connectionless and provides best-effort delivery with no guarantees. Upper-layer protocols (like TCP) handle reliability, tracking, and retransmission.

importantPoints: Layer 3 encapsulation adds source and destination IP addresses
Routers forward packets based on destination IP address only
IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses; IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses
IPv6 header is simpler and more efficient than IPv4 header
The loopback address is 127.0.0.1 (used to test local TCP/IP stack)
Packets on the same LAN are sent directly without using the default gateway
Packets to remote networks are sent to the default gateway first
TTL (IPv4) or Hop Limit (IPv6) prevents packets from looping forever
Each router decrements TTL/Hop Limit by 1; packet dropped if it reaches 0
Destination IP address stays the same during transmission; TTL changes
The MTU is determined by Layer 2 and passed to Layer 3
IP is connectionless; reliability must be handled by upper layers (TCP)
show ip route is a Cisco IOS command, not a Windows command
